unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: One-Sample $T$ Hypothesis of Ice Water
question_text:
Suppose a psychologist decides to use a matched pairs (paired) experiment to determine how long individuals can hold their hands in ice water when intoxicated compared to sober.
Suppose the psychologist hypothesizes that alcohol will numb the pain, so individuals will be able to keep their hands in the ice water longer when intoxicated.
If the longest amount of time was $5.1\text{ minutes}$, what are the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses for this situation?

choices.text:
$H_0: { u }_{ 1 }= { u }_{ 2 }$
$H_a: { u }_{ 1 }< { u }_{ 2 }$
Define ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when intoxicated, and ${ u }_{ 2 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when sober.

$H_0: { u }_{ 1 }={ u }_{ 2 }$
$H_a: { u }_{ 1 } > { u }_{ 2 }$
Define ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when intoxicated and ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when sober.

$H_0: \mu = 0$
$H_a: \mu > 0$
Define $\mu$ as the increase in time an individual can hold their hands in ice water when intoxicated.

$H_0: \mu = 5.1$
$H_a: \mu < 5. 1$
Define $\mu$ as the average amount of time an individual can hold their hands in ice water.

$H_0: \mu = 0$
$H_a: \mu < 0$
Define $\mu$ as the increase in time an individual can hold their hands in ice water when intoxicated.

solution:
A matched pairs experiment examines only the difference between two treatments. In this situation, the psychologist hypothesizes an increase in the time hands can be held in ice water; $\mu > 0$ hints there could be an increase in the difference in times hands can be held in ice water (intoxicated vs. sober).

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' and 'B' are incorrect; these are meant for $T$ procedures involving two independent samples.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this involves the value $5.1$, which is the longest time a person was able to hold their hands in the ice water. This value should have nothing to do with setting up hypotheses.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; this gives an alternative hypothesis that intoxicated individuals will be able to hold their hands in ice water for less time. This is not what the question phrases.
